Lafont explicitly states that her secularistic citizen would, in contrast, object to the unequal treatment involved in denying the right to marriage to a group of citizens or appeal to anti-discrimination laws (Lafont, 2009: 142). But this is tantamount to refraining from a public use of secularism, which is precisely what Habermas’ perspective proposes.

At least to a certain degree, Lafont’s secularistic citizen has to distance herself from her secularism in order to be able to find the motivation for offering those arguments, instead of just offering the most sincere argument she has and believes in, namely, that religion is the opiate of the people and that a person under the effect of such ‘substance’ should not be listened to. It is difficult to believe that a citizen who ‘goes’ to the debates in the public sphere with such beliefs will be able to take seriously her fellow religious citizens as potentially reasonable contributors, since she clearly and undoubtedly strikes them down from the beginning for using religious language, language that, for Habermas, has a powerful semantic content that can make relevant contributions to public discussions.

Moreover, there are certain arguments that do not seem to belong to the public sphere. Clearly, Lafont’s right to include in public political debates any perspective or argument one honestly believes is not posited without limits. Indeed, for Lafont herself such a right has to be combined with the ‘need to secure reasons acceptable to everyone for the coercive political decisions with which all citizens must comply’ (Lafont, 2009: 141).

There are easy cases of cognitive stances not protected by such a right. If we wanted to accept Lafont’s proposal, we would have to affirm that some cognitive stances simply do not secure reasons acceptable to everyone. For instance, a citizen should not be entitled to a cognitive belief according to which she can refuse to listen to a person for reasons related to her race, gender, age, social origin, etc. To be sure, no truly democratic citizen would be entitled to offer a counter-argument according to which one of her fellow citizens’ reasons are mistaken because she is a woman, or because she is an immigrant. In this sense Lafont’s right does not protect racist cognitive stances insofar as they are not the beliefs that a democratic citizen would hold. 25 Similarly, if we look at her examples, Lafont does not want to protect either the possibility of being able to offer an argument like the following: ‘Your religious argument cannot be accepted because it is religious.’ She is more interested in arguments with the following structure: ‘Your religious argument cannot be accepted because it contradicts the principle of equality established in our constitution.’

But such a secular citizen, as it was shown before, has to accept at least the presentation of the religious argument. In this sense, the secularistic citizens would have to accept that religious arguments are allowed in the public sphere. If sincerity were her only motivation, a secularistic citizen who thought that religions are dangerous holdovers that should be openly combated would only offer the following answer to a religious argument: ‘You have a deceived consciousness.’

Thus, her radical secularism, even for Lafont, must be partially affected by her participation in the debate and the acceptance of the presentation of religious arguments. However, if religious arguments are accepted, it is because those arguments constitute potentially relevant contributions offered by other citizens. Once a religious argument is accepted in the public sphere it means that religious conceptions of the world might have some potential for truth and that citizens can make contributions to public debates phrased in religious language. Therefore, all the citizens participating in the debate have the duty of listening, and, if possible, even the duty of attempting to translate the valuable semantic content of the religious argument into a language accessible to all citizens (Habermas, 2006b: 260).

Now, does this mean that Habermas’ rejection of a public secularism requires the acceptance of a private one? Does this mean that Habermas is encouraging citizens to be hypocrites who do not affirm in public what they really think in private? I think that on this issue it is crucial to highlight that what is at stake is an ethics of citizenship. A secularistic citizen might have to split her mind, but how she does it is entirely up to her. An easy way to do it is to reject secularism. But, offering an account of this process is not the job for an ethics of citizenship; an ethics that is ultimately interested, not in personal mind-sets, but in the public utterances that citizens actually express for the legitimizing power of democratic discourses. In this sense, ultimately Lafont agrees with Habermas in that, at least in the public sphere, the secularistic citizen has to restrain her own secularism. As Lafont herself puts it, ‘There is no cognitive dishonesty involved in being exposed to the arguments of our fellow citizens or in being obliged to make our own arguments good by appeal to arguments that other citizens can reasonably accept’ (Lafont, 2007: 252). Thus, the secularist citizen, in her role of citizen, is not being dishonest if she refrains from secularistic views that deny any value for religious discourses.

sec.title: Objection four
sec.p: The fourth objection to Habermas’ approach refers to the apparent silence from Habermas about citizens’ obligation when casting their votes. According to Lafont, there is not enough clarity in Habermas’ proposal on the central question of how citizens should act when casting their votes. For Lafont, Habermas seems to be accepting that religious citizens may ‘cast their votes on the basis of their religious convictions … However, it should be obvious that allowing a majority of religious citizens to cast their votes on fundamental political questions on the basis of exclusively religious reasons would directly undermine the central normative claim of Habermas’ approach, namely, that only secular reasons should count in determining coercive political decisions’ (Lafont, 2009: 140).

Lafont’s fourth objection deserves a deep analysis insofar as it points out that the frontier dividing the formal public sphere and the informal is, to say the least, porous, especially when discussing religion’s role. Habermas, to be sure, is not unaware of this. Indeed, he also raises the question ‘of the extent to which during an election campaign candidates may confess or even indicate that they are religious persons’ (Habermas, 2008: 128). In this sense, a complete response to this objection would take us to the ways in which the informal and the formal public sphere interact with each other in order to transform political power into public will. In this article, nonetheless, I do not have the space for fully developing a response in that direction.

I do want to indicate, anyway, that Habermas has a good reason for not considering voting as an important issue. As he puts it:
What is illegitimate is of course not the majority vote, assuming it has been correctly carried out, but the violation of the other core component of the procedure, namely the discursive nature of the deliberations preceding the vote … Majority rule turns into repression if the majority deploys religious arguments in the process of political opinion and will formation and refuses to offer those publicly accessible justifications which the losing minority, be it secular or of a different faith, is able to follow and to evaluate in the light of shared standards. (Habermas, 2006a: 12)

Nevertheless, I think that Lafont’s disagreement with Habermas is based on the place she assigns to sincerity for assessing public discussions. Going back to our example, we could think that the religious citizen who proposed the poll did it because she knew that, numerically, there are more Radical Religious and Soft Religious citizens than Soft Atheists and Radical Atheists. We could also think that she made her proposal with the hope that, ultimately, many of her fellow religious citizens, at the moment of voting, would say: ‘OK, I like equality, and I said in the debate that I respected it, but, sorry, I am a good Catholic and the Church is opposed to same-sex marriages, so I vote negatively.’

Doubtless, this is something that can happen in reality. However, as Habermas indicates:
… the link between the actual motivation for a citizen’s actions and those reasons he cites in public may be relevant for a moral judgment of the citizen, but it has no import for assessing his contribution to maintaining a liberal political culture. For in the final analysis, only the manifest reasons have institutional implications for the formation of majorities and decision-making within the relevant political bodies. (Habermas, 2008: 126)

Thus, the voting objection is compelling as long as one emphasizes sincerity as a crucial element that defines the ethics of citizenship. However, if, as Habermas sees it, what is important for the legitimizing power of democratic discourses is not mind-sets but actual contributions to the formation of opinions and consensus-building (Habermas, 2011: 33), then at the end of the day one can only hope that, when facing the ballots, a religious democratic citizen would integrate within her religious world-view the requirements of the liberal state.

sec.title: Objection five
sec.p: Lafont’s last objection is that, at the end of the day, Habermas’ proposal can only be applied in societies less pluralistic than the actual existing ones; societies in which Radical Religious and Radical Atheist citizens do not exist.

The response to this fifth objection might have two faces. On the one hand, it could simply be said that Habermas is developing a normative-philosophical approach on how citizens should act. Nonetheless, I do not think that Lafont is pointing to this with her objection. But, she does affirm that ‘Certainly, no one would deny that if citizens’ cognitive stances were to become similar enough the problem of political integration would eventually disappear. But, it can hardly count as a way to solve the problem of political integration under conditions of pluralism to simply hope that the problem evaporates if and when some extremes of the spectrum disappear’ (Lafont, 2009: 147). In this sense, Lafont’s criticism seems to be motivated by a defense of pluralism. Nonetheless, it is true that, from Habermas’ proposal, some of the Radical Religious citizens and Radical Atheist citizens cannot be truly democratic citizens if they maintain their cognitive stances and make use of them in public debates. However, Radical Atheist citizens willing to doubt their own secularism as well as Radical Religious citizens able to integrate egalitarianism into their religious doctrines are in a very different position.

Second, as it was mentioned in the response to Lafont’s third objection, it is not clear what Lafont means when she posits the right of all democratic citizens to take their own cognitive stance in public deliberations. In a deliberative democracy, as Lafont herself acknowledges, this right would have to be coherent with the duties of a democratic citizen; duties that, as Habermas has indicated, affect the cognitive stances that such a citizen is allowed to have. In Lafont’s words:
Although democratic societies may in fact contain citizens who do not endorse democratic political values, only if a majority of citizens endorses them can a democratic regime be sustained in the long run. It is against the background of that aim that an account of the moral obligations of democratic citizenship makes sense. Since citizens who reject democratic political values would equally reject any democratic obligation to provide reasons acceptable to other citizens for coercive policies to which all must comply, they are beyond the reach of any account of the moral obligations of democratic citizenship that make public justification possible. For better or for worse, an account of the democratic obligations of citizenship can only reach democratic citizens. (Lafont, 2009: 145–6)

Hence, although it is true that, as Lafont says, ‘politics is the realm of the here and now’ (2009: 140), it is also true that Habermas is developing a normative approach directed to those citizens willing to be democratic and, thus, willing to live in the United States of Deliberative Democracies. And this, according to Habermas, requires cognitive preconditions that all citizens (religious and non-religious) must fulfill (Habermas, 2006a: 18).

No democratic citizen is entitled to a cognitive belief according to which the arguments provided in a public debate by a dark-skinned female citizen do not have, from the beginning, the same weight as the arguments of other citizens. In this sense, a democratic state demands that its citizens be open-minded enough to hear the reasons and arguments of other fellow citizens without denying them any possible value, validity, or truthfulness. Although the reasons are different, Habermas’ account of the role of religion in the public sphere highlights that just as a democratic citizen cannot have the right to affirm in a public debate: ‘I do not have to listen to your arguments because you are black’ (or a woman, or poor, or liberal, or immigrant, etc.), that very same democratic citizen cannot have the right, either, to affirm in a public debate: ‘I do not have to listen to your arguments because you can only formulate them in a religious language.’

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Lafont acknowledges that ‘Religious citizens cannot justify the policies they favor on the basis of exclusively religious claims and reasons simply because they live in societies with secular citizens and citizens of conflicting faiths’ (Lafont, 2007: 252). According to Habermas, religious citizens can formulate their arguments in a religious language, but they do it knowing that they are constrained by their previous acceptance of the constitution of the secular state. Likewise, secular citizens cannot entirely rule out religious arguments from the informal public sphere because they live in societies with religious citizens of very different and diverse faiths, who are protected, in a form of a legal right, by that very same secular constitution.

In this sense, Habermas’ proposal on the role of religion in the public sphere implies a great advantage that must be highlighted. Indeed, Habermas’ account does not aim to distinguish between rational religious doctrines and irrational ones. For him, ‘in the final instance it is the faith and practice of the religious community that decide whether a dogmatic processing of the cognitive challenges of modernity has been “successful” or not; only then can believers accept it as a “learning process”’ (Habermas, 2008: 138). Nonetheless, Habermas’ proposal also clarifies that, from the perspective of the constitution of the liberal state, religious doctrines will indeed be differentiated on the basis of whether or not they cope with the fact of pluralism, with the public authority of the sciences, and with the egalitarianism of our constitutional principles. But, in addition, from the very same perspective of the liberal state, it is expected that secular citizens will draw such distinction as well.

At first sight, the public debates about same-sex marriages would not seem to constitute a good case for emphasizing the positive aspects of religious doctrines for a deliberative democracy. However, with my example I tried to show that religious doctrines are so diverse and complex that even within the seemingly negative role that they play in the debates about same-sex marriages, the door must be left opened for the introduction of other kinds of religious arguments that point at a different direction. Be that as it may, I think that the example of a public debate about same-sex marriage was useful to show that Habermas’ approach does not represent a blind defense of religion.

Although I do not think that Lafont’s objections are as strong as she claimed them to be, her critiques do constitute useful indicators of Habermas’ strong presuppositions on which his account of the role of religion in the public sphere is based. In rejecting Lafont’s objections I do not want to suggest that Habermas’ perspective is flawless. Nonetheless, I think that Habermas’ flaws and problems are to be found within the philosophical bases on which his account rests. I would like to end my article by indicating what I regard as the most important conceptual presuppositions of Habermas’ account. I want to present the following remarks as preliminary reflections that might be helpful at developing a more thorough and systematic critique of Habermas’ account of the role of religion in the public sphere.

First, as the response to Lafont’s objections revealed, Habermas is presupposing an account of what religion is and why it is a very special and unique comprehensive doctrine. According to Lafont, Habermas’ participation in the debate about the role of religion in the public sphere seems surprising ‘since religion has rarely been foregrounded in his work’ (Lafont, 2007: 239). Nevertheless, already in his doctoral dissertation, religion was a theme of reflection for Habermas. Moreover, according to Habermas himself, his interest on religion is something that he has never truly abandoned:
I would not object to the claim that my conception of language and of communicative action oriented toward mutual understanding nourishes itself from the legacy of Christianity. The ‘telos of reaching understanding’ … may well nourish itself from the heritage of a logos understood as Christian, one that is indeed embodied … in the communicative practice of the religious congregation. Already the communicative-theoretical version of the concept of emancipation in Knowledge and Human Interest could be ‘unmasked’ as the secularizing translation of the divine promise of salvation. (Habermas, 2002: 160)

It should be analysed nonetheless, to what extent Habermas’ perspective on religion has substantially changed in his most recent works. In addition, it is fair to wonder whether or not his new view of religion is coherent with the rest of his system of communicative rationality.

Second, it is noteworthy that Habermas claims to be developing a post-metaphysical approach to religion. According to him, this type of approach is able to enter into dialogue with religious doctrines. I think that in order to assess Habermas’ perspective on religion we must bear in mind its alleged post-metaphysical character. In this sense, his account of the role of religion in the public sphere is based on a premise that cannot go unnoticed, namely, that only a post-metaphysical philosophy is able to understand the post-secular character of the current world society. 26

For Habermas, post-metaphysical thinking expresses the kind of cognitive attitude that secular citizens must develop in order to fully respect their fellow religious citizens and learn from their contributions to public debates. In his words, ‘the secular awareness that one is living in a post-secular society finds expression at the philosophical level in a post-metaphysical mode of thought’ (Habermas, 2008: 119). It remains to be analysed, among other issues, to what extent what Habermas means by this is that all secular citizens have to be post-metaphysical thinkers in order to be democratic.

Third, Habermas’ latest interest in religion is based on a political perspective of a deliberative democracy. In this sense, there exists a deep relationship between Habermas’ approach to religion and his democratic attempt to find a new meaning for the concept of ‘the political’. Indeed, Habermas’ ‘revival’ of ‘the political’ implies that religion cannot be considered as something necessarily anti-Enlightenment or anti-modernity. Religion, actually, should be considered as an authentic source of ‘salvation’ for the motivational deficit largely found within the liberal states (Habermas, 2011). For Habermas, simply put, citizens are being rendered powerless by the economic and administrative subsystems, and one way to oppose that process is by their self-empowerment as truly politically committed agents who maintain a normative perspective according to which ‘something better is still available to get’. Regarding this aspect, nonetheless, it is at least counter-intuitive that the salvation for democracy has to be found in religious communities, communities whose structure has not been historically characterized by their democratic shape.

Finally, as properly noted by Lafont, the notion itself of modernity is also at stake, or, in other words, a reflexive self-understanding of modernity and the role religion plays within such self-understanding. In Habermas’ words, ‘The controversy also extends to the epistemological question of the relationship between faith and knowledge, which itself impinges upon key elements of the background understanding of modernity. Interestingly enough, both the philosophical and the theological efforts to define the relationship between faith and knowledge in a self-reflexive manner throw up far-reaching questions concerning the genealogy of modernity’ (Habermas, 2008: 145). Thus, although Habermas’ proposal refers to deliberative democracies, its context is also the current emergence of a world society and a global public sphere that affects the type of consciousness and the degree of self-reflexivity expected of democratic citizens.

fn.p: Habermas’ main text on the subject is ‘Religion in the Public Sphere’ published in 2006 in the European Journal of Philosophy. There is another version of the text published a year before in Zwischen Naturalismus und Religion. The English translation of this latter text is ‘Religion in the Public Sphere: Cognitive Presuppositions for the “Public Use of Reason” by Religious and Secular Citizens’. It is noteworthy that Habermas also explains his perspective in his text ‘On the Relations Between the Secular Liberal State and Religion’ published in Political Theologies: Public Religions in a Post-Secular World in 2006.

Lafont’s articles are ‘Religion in the Public Sphere: Remarks on Habermas’s Conception of Public Deliberation in Postsecular Societies’, (2007) and ‘Religion and the Public Sphere: What are the Deliberative Obligations of Democratic Citizenship?’, (2009).

Habermas distinguishes between ‘secular’ and ‘secularist’. In his own words:
I make a terminological distinction between ‘secular’ and ‘secularist’. Unlike the neutral stance of a secular or unbelieving person who regards religious validity claims agnostically, secularists adopt a polemical stance towards religious doctrines which retain a certain public influence even though their claims cannot be scientifically justified. Today secularism often appeals to a ‘hard’, that is, scientifically grounded, version of naturalism. (Habermas, 2009: 74) In Between Naturalism and Religion Habermas had already stated that ‘The secularism of the scientific worldview insists that the archaic ways of thinking of religious doctrines have been completely overtaken and made redundant by the advances in knowledge of established research’ (Habermas, 2008: 5).

For Lafont the most obvious virtue of Habermas’ proposal is that it does not demand self-restraint from religious citizens for the kind of arguments they can provide in the deliberative agenda of the informal public sphere. Nevertheless, Lafont acknowledges that Habermas does not emphasize this aspect. For her, though, such absence of self-restraint is an essential feature of any credible account of deliberative democracy (Lafont, 2007: 244–5).

Throughout her texts Lafont raises several objections against Habermas’ perspective. However, the objections that she really develops are the ones related to the basis of her own proposal. I think, nonetheless, that each one of Lafont’s objections points to crucial elements of Habermas’ account that need to be analysed more carefully. In this sense I will try to derive from Lafont’s own texts objections that perhaps are presented by her only as problematic questions.

It is well known that citizens’ perspective on same-sex marriage is highly influenced by their religion. According to the 2010 Annual Religion and Public Life Survey conducted by Pew Research Center for the People & the Press and the Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life 35% of citizens admit that religion is the top influence on their thinking about same-sex marriage. One of the conclusions of the poll survey was that ‘In contrast with many other social and political issues, religion is clearly an important influence on public opinion about same-sex marriage and abortion. Significant numbers of Americans report that religion is the most important factor in their thinking about these topics, and sizeable numbers of churchgoers hear about them from their clergy.’ See: http://pewforum.org/Politics-and-Elections/Few-Say-Religion-Shapes-Immigration-Environment-Views.aspx#3

To be sure, Lafont also demands a justification from Habermas regarding his idea that, in order to be rational and democratic, a religious citizen must accept the authority of scientific knowledge. In Lafont’s words:
In general, I find Habermas’ diagnosis of the changes in mentality required of religious and secular citizens in a post-secular society highly problematic. Being a secular citizen myself, I certainly would welcome the acceptance of the authority of scientific knowledge by everyone, religious citizens included. From an epistemic point of view, I do not see any rational alternative. But, even so, I fail to see how this could suffice to justify the quite different claim that accepting the authority of science is a precondition for fulfilling the normative expectations of democratic citizenship. Habermas nowhere provides a substantive justification of this claim, though one seems urgently needed. (Lafont, 2009: 146)

In her proposal, Lafont highlights the existence of arguments to which every citizen, whether secular or religious, is obliged to respond. Let us suppose that a Soft Religious citizen argues that the law should be accepted in virtue of the intrinsic value of homosexual life-styles. To be sure, this citizen is absolutely entitled to offer her argument. However, it is an argument to which other citizens may not feel compelled to respond. However, if the argument in favor of same-sex marriage is similar to the ones mentioned before, namely, arguments about the political value of equal treatment to all citizens, this argument does need to be answered by the religious citizens that oppose same-sex marriage. In this case, they have to explain why their opposition does not imply an institutionalizing of a second-class citizenship for same-sex couples.

As I said before, Lafont’s ‘mediator interpretation’ is not completely inaccurate since Habermas himself affirms that his conception ‘mediates between the two sides’ (Habermas, 2008: 119; emphases added) of the debate. Based on her ‘mediator interpretation’ Lafont raises what could be a sixth objection to Habermas’ account, namely, his unjustified commitment with equal distribution or symmetry as a criterion for assessing the cognitive burdens of both secular and religious citizens. At many moments, according to Lafont, it seems that political fairness constitutes Habermas’ rationale for allowing religious citizens to offer exclusively religious arguments in the discussions within the informal public sphere. Once again, Lafont is not completely groundless in pointing out Habermas’ commitment with symmetry. Indeed, Habermas recurrently shows that his proposal is strongly committed to it. In Habermas’ own words: ‘what interests me is the unanswered question whether the revised concept of citizenship that I have proposed in fact imposes an asymmetrical burden on religious traditions and religious communities after all’ (Habermas, 2006a:14; emphasis added). Also, right after presenting his controversial burdens on secular citizens, he states: ‘This requirement of translation must be conceived as a cooperative task in which the non-religious citizens must likewise participate, if their religious fellow citizens are not to be encumbered with an asymmetrical burden’ (Habermas 2006a:11; emphasis added). Finally, at the end of his text, Habermas concludes:
The required work of philosophical reconstruction goes to show that the ethics of democratic citizenship assumes secular citizens exhibit a mentality that is no less demanding than the corresponding mentality of their religious counterparts. This is why the cognitive burdens that both sides have to shoulder in order to acquire the appropriate epistemic attitudes are by no means asymmetrically distributed. (Habermas, 2006a:18; emphasis added)

For Lafont, nonetheless, as long as the cognitive burdens are well justified, it is not clear at all why, in addition, they have to be symmetrically distributed. As she puts it:
Thus it may well be that the cognitive burdens democracy imposes on different citizens actually are not symmetrical. However, to the same extent that cognitive stances cannot be chosen or prescribed from the outside, it makes no sense to think that the consequences of adopting them can be regulated through a fair distribution of cognitive burdens. (Lafont, 2007: 253)

Briefly put, this sixth objection would indicate that symmetry cannot be taken as a criterion to develop a proper account of the ethics of citizenship. In Lafont’s words:
… there is no a priori guarantee that the request for symmetrical distribution of cognitive burdens among citizens will be compatible with the discursive conditions necessary for a meaningful process of political opinion- and willformation through collective deliberation in the public sphere. Given that such conditions, whatever they turn out to be, must have priority in a discourse account of the ethics of democratic citizenship, if a deliberative democracy is to be possible at all, the discourse approach must leave open the question of whether or not the cognitive burdens that derive from such conditions turn out to be symmetrically distributed among citizens. (Lafont, 2007: 259)
Although I will not deepen this line of argumentation, I must admit that I too regard as misleading Habermas’ references to symmetry.

Perhaps an argument from a secularistic perspective might imply a radical naturalistic view. In this sense, then, a Radical Atheist might affirm that homosexuality is simply a by-product of evolution. He could use as proof for his argument some of the researches that document ‘similar’ behaviors in other species. One of the most recent cases that received the attention of the media refers to the Laysan albatross, Phoebastria immutabilis (see Lindsay C. Young, Brenda J. Zaun and Eric A. VanderWerf, ‘Successful Same-sex Pairing in Laysan Albatross’, Biol Lett. 4(4) (23 August 2008): 323–5). Bruce Bagemihl's book Biological Exuberance: Animal Homosexuality and Natural Diversity (New York: St Martin's Press, 1999) is commonly quoted for stating that various forms of same-sex sexual activity have been observed in more than 450 different species of animals. In this sense the argument is the following: if homosexual behavior occurs in animals, then it means that it is something natural. Therefore, since such behavior does occur in many other animals, homosexuality should be accepted and the rights of same-sex couples should be protected. Human beings, at the end of day, are just another kind of animal and not the rulers of creation like many religious doctrines suggest (‘Let us make man in our image, in our likeness, and let them rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air, over the livestock, over all the earth, and over all the creatures that move along the ground’ [Genesis 1:26]). But if this kind of argument is radicalized we might be now in terrain in which it might presuppose the idea that every human sphere (sexuality included) must be interpreted only from a biological and evolutionary perspective, In this sense, any religious counter-argument is seen as an unnecessary and false moral perspective introduced into what can and should be interpreted exclusively in naturalistic terms. Now, expressed like this the argument reveals its radical scientistic character. And, in this sense, as Boettcher indicates, ‘At least in their role as citizens, the non-religious must also be able to distinguish science from scientism and related forms of philosophical naturalism’ (Boettcher, 2009: 232). In Habermas’ words:
Scientism often misleads us into blurring the boundary between natural scientific knowledge which is relevant for understanding ourselves and our place in nature as a whole, on the one hand, and a synthetic naturalistic worldview constructed on this basis, on the other. This form of radical naturalism devalues all types of statements that cannot be traced back to empirical observations, statements of laws, or causal explanations, hence moral, legal, and evaluative statements no less than religious ones. (Habermas, 2008: 141)

Similarly:
In theoretical controversies, scientific specialization is sufficient to pre-empt the practical lifeworld conflicts that erupt in religious disputes because religious truths have immediate relevance for the personal conduct of one’s life. Scientists are drawn into such conflicts only when the practice of research promises to have implications for the ethical self-understanding of persons beyond the domain of research … As it happens, this shows that a naturalism based on a synthetic treatment of scientific information is itself a worldview and is situated on the same level as religious interpretations as far as the relevance of knowledge for ethical action goes. (Habermas, 2008: 259–60)

In ‘Religion in the Public Sphere’ Habermas makes the same claim by saying that ‘the liberal state … must not discourage religious persons and communities from also expressing themselves politically as such, for it cannot know whether secular society would not otherwise cut itself off from key resources for the creation of meaning and identity’ (Habermas, 2006a: 10).

In the interview ‘A Conversation About God and The World’, published in 2002 in Religion and Rationality, Eduardo Mendieta asked Habermas the following: ‘Is it your view that it is philosophy’s goal to completely assimilate, to translate, to rework and to “sublate” all desirable religious content? Or do you expect that religion will forever resist all efforts at such an intervention – and that it thus always will remain unassimilable and inaccessible, and in a certain sense thus also autonomous and unavoidable?’ Habermas’ answer was: ‘I don’t know.’ (Habermas, 2002: 163).

This was one of the deepest disagreements between Habermas and Taylor in the panel ‘Rethinking Secularism: The Power of Religion in the Public Sphere’ hosted in fall 2009 by the NYU's Institute for Public Knowledge, the Social Science Research Council and Stony Brook University. For Taylor, religion is simply one instance of many sorts of comprehensive views of the good. In contrast, for Habermas, religion is a very special case. As he puts it, ‘the evidence for religious reasons does not only depend on cognitive beliefs and their semantic nexus with other beliefs, but on existential beliefs that are rooted in the social dimension of membership, socialization, and prescribed practices’ (Habermas, 2011: 62. It seems to me that Lafont’s reluctance to engage Habermas’ thoughts on religion might presuppose her agreement with Taylor’s perspective.

See ‘A Postsecular World Society? On the Philosophical Significance of Postsecular Consciousness and the Multicultural World Society’. Jürgen Habermas Interviewed by Eduardo Mendieta, available March 2011 @: http://mrzine.monthlyreview.org/2010/habermas210310.html

In this same interview Habermas recognizes, nonetheless, that his criticism, directed against the laicist understanding of the separation of state and church, can be regarded as a European view. For Habermas, in the United States, where ‘the President publicly prays in office, the criticism that orients itself by the same principles should aim in the opposite political direction. In my view, positions that do not wish to subject the political influence of religious voices to formal constraints blur the limits without which a secular state cannot maintain its impartiality.’ Furthermore, Habermas even admits that ‘the political cultures are already so different between our Western societies that the universal principles for the public role of religion – in general, for what we in the West call the “separation of church and state” – would have to be specified and institutionalized differently in each local context’.

For Lafont, ‘Whereas citizens may not feel compelled to address objections based, say, on the intrinsic value of homosexual life-styles or of cultural diversity, which they may not share, they must feel compelled to address objections based on the political value of equal treatment that they do share as democratic citizens’ (Lafont, 2009: 142).

In Habermas’ words: ‘After all, the conflict between one’s own religious convictions and secularly justified policies or proposed laws can only arise because even the religious citizen is already supposed to have accepted the constitution of the secular state for good reasons. He no longer lives as a member of a religiously homogeneous population within a religiously legitimated state’ (Habermas, 2008: 129).

In this sense, the question that seems to define Lafont's proposal is the following: ‘[I]s it at all possible to organize public deliberation in such a way that none of the tasks involved require democratic citizens to adopt a disingenuous cognitive stance, while at the same time meeting the liberal criterion of democratic legitimacy? (Lafont, 2009: 141).

In a certain way, Habermas’ perspective is related to Kant’s duty to respect every human being in the logical use of reason. For Kant, such duty must be thought of as
… a duty not to censure his error by calling them absurdities, poor judgment and so forth, but rather to suppose that his judgment must yet contain some truth and to seek this out, uncovering, at the same time, the deceptive illusion (the subjective ground that determined his judgment which, by an oversight, he took for objective), and so, by explaining to him the possibility of his having erred, to preserve his respect for his own understanding. For if, by using such expressions, one denies any understanding to someone who opposes one in a certain judgment, how does one want to bring him to understand that he has erred? (2009: 6:463)

Lafont offers two slightly different formulations of this right. First, she formulates it as the right to include in public political debate whatever views and reasons one honestly believes. But, second, she also refers to the right of all democratic citizens to take their own cognitive stance in public deliberation. It is noteworthy that in the second formulation the adjective ‘democratic’ might work as a filter for excluding certain cognitive stances. If a citizen would say, for instance, ‘Your argument is not strong because you are a woman’, one could say that such cognitive stance is not one that a democratic citizen would hold. In the first case, there does not seem any filter and every cognitive stance would seem to be allowed, even if it were discriminatory or degrading. Although Lafont is ambiguous in this aspect, the examples she offers as acceptable arguments seem to indicate that she is referring to the second case.

For Habermas, philosophy needs to leave behind its ‘metaphysical past’ in order to develop an appropriate understanding of its coexistence with religious practice. Philosophy should not overstep its own boundaries by conceiving of itself as a replacement of religion.
